article.h1: ON THE DETERMINATION OF STAR FORMATION RATES IN EVOLVING GALAXY POPULATIONS

span.span: Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, Prince Consort Rd, London SW7 2BW, UK
School of Physics, University of Sydney, Sydney NSW 2006, Australia
Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, Prince Consort Rd, London SW7 2BW, UK

div.p: The redshift dependence of the luminosity density in certain wavebands (e.g. UV and HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha) can be used to infer the history of star formation in the populations of galaxies producing this luminosity. This history is a useful datum in studies of galaxy evolution. It is therefore important to understand the errors that attend the inference of star formation rate densities from luminosity densities. This paper explores the self-consistency of star formation rate diagnostics by reproducing commonly used observational procedures in a model with known galaxy populations, evolutionary histories and spectral emission properties. The study reveals a number of potential sources of error in the diagnostic processes arising from the differential evolution of different galaxy types. We argue that multi-wavelength observations can help to reduce these errors.

article.div: cosmology: observations â€” galaxies: evolution â€” stars: formation

span.span: â€ slugcomment: Accepted for publication in the Astrophysical Journal

div.p: The stellar content and hence the spectral energy distribution (SED) of a galaxy depends on many factors. Accurate predictions of galaxy SEDs require sound theories of stellar evolution and stellar atmospheres, including transient and extreme phases that remain difficult to model. In addition, the evolution of a galaxy SED depends on (i) the initial mass function (IMF) of stars and (ii) the history of the star formation rate (SFR). Parts of the SED, such as the UV continuum and the Balmer lines, are sensitive to the recent IMF and SFR, while other parts, such as the IR continuum, reflect long-term averages. This opens the possibility of using observations of SEDs to determine the current and past SFR in a particular galaxy, and, by observing the SEDs of populations of galaxies over a range of redshifts, the history of star formation in the universe. To do this, one needs a galaxy spectral synthesis model connecting SEDs with SFRs and IMFs. Early models of this kind were reviewed by Tinsley & Danly (1980), and more recent work is summarised by Leitherer et al. (1996) and Schaerer (1999).

The past decade or so has seen the acquisition of a rapidly growing body of data on the distribution, over redshift, absolute luminosity, and galaxy type, of those spectral properties of galaxies sensitive to star formation rates. Particularly notable have been new data on rest-frame UV luminosities to redshifts zâ‰ˆ4ğ‘§4italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:4z\approx 4 (Lilly et al., 1996; Madau et al., 1996; Cowie et al., 1997; Connolly et al., 1997; Madau, Pozzetti & Dickinson, 1998; Pascarelle, Lanzetta & FernÃ¡ndez-Soto, 1998; Treyer et al., 1998; Cowie, Songaila & Barger, 1999; Sullivan et al., 1999), emission line luminosities in HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ and [Oii] Î»â¢372ğœ†372italic-lambda NUMBER:372\lambda 372Â nm to zâ‰ˆ1ğ‘§1italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1z\approx 1 (Gallego et al., 1995; Cowie et al., 1997; Tresse & Maddox, 1998; Glazebrook et al., 1998), and photometry (with redshift estimates to zâ‰ˆ1ğ‘§1italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1z\approx 1) in the far-IR, sub-mm and radio spectral bands (Rowan-Robinson et al., 1997; Flores et al., 1999; Hughes et al., 1998; Blain et al., 1999; Cram et al., 1998). The data have been interpreted by several of these authors using galaxy spectral synthesis models, to yield estimates of the star formation rate as a function of redshift.

Although it is widely recognised that there are numerous sources of uncertainty in the process of inferring star formation rates from the observable diagnostics, there have been few systematic, internally consistent investigations of these uncertainties (see also Schaerer, 1999). In an attempt to bridge this gap, this paper uses a galaxy spectral evolution code to test the self-consistency of common diagnostic procedures. We do this by comparing the known star formation history of a model universe containing specified galaxy populations with the star formation history that would be inferred by applying commonly adopted diagnostic procedures. Two questions are addressed: (1) are star formation rates derived from HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ and UV luminosities consistent with each other?, and (2) are star formation rates inferred from luminosity densities consistent with the true star formation rate in the model? It is important to stress that we do not aim to explore the validity of any particular model of cosmic star formation history: we are concerned here only with checking the internal consistency of diagnostic procedures.

We use the galaxy spectral evolution model pegase (Fioc & Rocca-Volmerange, 1997) and the galaxy population evolution model of Pozzetti, Bruzual & Zamorani (1996) to predict the evolution of the HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ and UV luminosity densities in a â€œmodel universeâ€ with a known star formation history. The key steps in our approach are (1) calculate the evolution of the actual SFR density defined by the parameters given in the model; (2) combine pegase and the model universe to predict the evolving luminosity densities; (3) use pegase to calibrate the SFR in terms of luminosity density using the methods commonly applied to observations, and (4) combine the calibration and the predicted luminosity density evolution to deduce the SFR history for comparison with step (1).

Pozzetti et al. (1996) explored pure luminosity evolution (PLE) models based on a mix of four galaxy types, E/S0, Sab-Sbc, Scd-Sdm and very Blue (vB). The different types are denoted hereinafter by the parameter kğ‘˜italic-kk. The local luminosity function Î¦kâ¢(L)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ¿Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-L CLOSE:)\Phi_{k}(L) of each type in each selected waveband is parametrised by the local space density Î¦kâˆ—superscriptsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜âˆ—Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Phi_{k}^{\ast}, characteristic luminosity Lkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ¿âˆ—ğ‘˜italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL^{\ast}_{k}, and faint-end slope Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{k}. Each type also has a characteristic IMF Î¨kâ¢(M)subscriptÎ¨ğ‘˜ğ‘€Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)\Psi_{k}(M) and star formation rate history, ÏË™kâ¢(t)subscriptË™ğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\dot{\rho}_{k}(t). A Scalo-type IMF is used for the E/S0 and Sab-Sbc types, hereinafter called â€œearlyâ€, while a Salpeter-type IMF is used for the Scd-Sdm and vB types, hereinafter called â€œlateâ€. For the E/S0 galaxies, Pozzetti et al.Â consider two models distinguished by different e-folding times (Ï„1,Ï„2subscriptğœ1subscriptğœ2italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{1},\tau_{2}) in their SFR. We adopt the Ï„2subscriptğœ2italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{2} model.

Pozzetti et al. (1996) constructed their model universe to match a number of observational constraints, including the source count distribution in several optical and IR photometric bands, the distribution of colours as a function of apparent magnitude, and the distribution of redshifts as a function of magnitude. Pozzetti et al. (1996) exhibit a PLE model which, in an Î©=0Î©0Omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Omega=0 Friedmann cosmology, leads to acceptable agreement with almost all of these constraints. They also deduce that PLE models in a flat (Î©=1Î©1Omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega=1) cosmology cannot reproduce several aspects of the data, and therefore we consider only the Î©=0Î©0Omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Omega=0 and H0=50subscriptğ»050italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:50H_{0}=50Â kmÂ s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â Mpc-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} model.

One constraint not used by Pozzetti et al.Â is the observed redshift dependence of the luminosity density in certain wavebands. FigureÂ 1 compares the UV luminosity density (â„’200superscriptâ„’200caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:200 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal L}^{200} â€“ see below) of the model of Pozzetti et al.Â with the observations of Cowie, Songaila & Barger (1999). While there remain significant uncertainties in the measured UV luminosity density (cf. Lilly et al., 1996; Cowie, Songaila & Barger, 1999; Sullivan et al., 1999), there is satisfactory agreement between the prediction and recent measurements. The significance of this will be amplified below.

Our application of pegase takes place in two steps. First, for galaxies of type kğ‘˜italic-kk we compute the time-dependent spectral emission which follows the instantaneous formation of 1 MâŠ™direct-productFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\odot} of stars. We use the evolutionary tracks of Bressan et al. (1993) supplemented to later evolutionary phases and to lower masses as indicated in Fioc & Rocca-Volmerange (1997). We use the spectral stellar library described by Fioc & Rocca-Volmerange (1997). We ignore extinction in the prediction of the UV luminosity, and assume the number of ionizing photons to be 70% of the Lyman continuum photons. To ensure agreement with the evolutionary tracks, pegase has an upper limit of 120 MâŠ™direct-productFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\odot} for the chosen IMFs. This leads to a minor inconsistency with the upper limit of 125 MâŠ™direct-productFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\odot} used by Pozzetti et al., but this has no effect on our conclusions.

In the second step we convolve the time-dependent spectral emission with the star formation rate history ÏË™kâ¢(t)subscriptË™ğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\dot{\rho}_{k}(t), to determine the evolution of Lkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ¿âˆ—ğ‘˜italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL^{\ast}_{k}. Inserted into the luminosity function in the model of Pozzetti et al.Â this yields a prediction of the luminosity density â„’kpâ¢(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘¡caligraphic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:){\cal L}_{k}^{p}(t) produced in the (rest-frame) waveband pğ‘italic-pp at time tğ‘¡italic-tt by the population kğ‘˜italic-kk undergoing star formation with a rate density of ÏË™kâ¢(t)subscriptË™ğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\dot{\rho}_{k}(t). The total SFR density is then clearly

div.p: and the total luminosity density in waveband pğ‘italic-pp is

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: For illustration it is convenient to define the ratio

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide caligraphic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: It is also convenient to define a global ratio for waveband pğ‘italic-pp as

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Our notation recognises that Rğ‘…italic-RR may be time dependent, and may depend on the galaxy type kğ‘˜italic-kk and waveband pğ‘italic-pp.

FiguresÂ 2(a) and (b) exhibit the evolution with time of Rkpâ¢(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{k}^{p}(t) for each galaxy type and of the global ratio Rpâ¢(t)superscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R^{p}(t), respectively for the 200Â nm continuum and for HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha. As previously stressed by Kennicutt (1983), Schaerer (1999) and others, the ratio for HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ in each galaxy type rapidly settles to a steady value, reflecting the fact that HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ emission is completely controlled by the short-lived, massive component of the IMF. The difference of â‰ˆ0.5absent0.5RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.5\approx 0.5 dex between the asymptotic ratios for the early and late-type galaxies is due to the adoption of Scalo and Salpeter IMFs, respectively, for the two types.

The evolution of Rkpâ¢(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{k}^{p}(t) for the 200Â nm continuum is quite complex. For the E/S0 type, in which most star formation takes place in the first 2 Gyr, the ratio displays a steady decline over â‰ˆ1absent1RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1\approx 1 Gyr, a plateau to â‰ˆ8absent8RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:8\approx 8 Gyr, and a subsequent decline to the present epoch. The initial decline arises from the rapid evolution of the initial burst, while the later decline reflects the late stages of evolution of relatively low mass stars at a time when few new stars are being born. The extended plateaux in the Sab-Sbc and Scd-Sdm types reflect the slower change in the star formation rate in these populations, while the difference in asymptotic value is due to the different IMFs. By definition, the vB component has a ratio equal to that of the Scd-Sdm type at an age of 100 Myr.

To emulate observational procedures, we require calibration constants Cpsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘italic-C POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC^{p} that do not depend on time or galaxy type. These have been estimated by previous workers using galaxy spectral synthesis models over a range of star-forming histories and ages, and selecting a â€œtypicalâ€ value (e.g. Kennicutt, Tamblyn & Congdon, 1994; Schaerer, 1999). We have conducted a similar study using pegase. As with previous derivations of calibration factors, we find a significant sensitivity to the IMF, but this is not the focus of our study. Accordingly, we explore calibrations based on both the Salpeter (â€œlateâ€) and Scalo (â€œearlyâ€) models adopted by Pozzetti et al.Â The calibration constants are listed in TableÂ 1. We acknowledge that there is inevitable uncertainty in the precise numerical values of the calibration factors in our study, as there is in other studies, but stress that this uncertainty has no effect on our conclusions.

section.h2: 3 THE INFERRED STAR FORMATION RATE AND ITS EVOLUTION

div.p: FigureÂ 3 exhibits the time dependent star formation rate density of each galaxy type, and for the totality of the populations. Early-type galaxies dominate star formation for z>1ğ‘§1italic-z RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1z>1, while all types except E/S0 contribute for zâ‰ˆ0ğ‘§0italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0z\approx 0. FigureÂ 4 shows the global star formation history that would be inferred from the luminosity densities using each of the calibration factors listed in TableÂ 1. Despite the self-consistency in our approach, in no case does the inferred value match the actual star formation history shown as the solid line in FiguresÂ 3 and 4.

There are two reasons for the discrepancies seen in FigureÂ 4 at z=0ğ‘§0italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0z=0. First, the fact that the early and late-type populations have different IMFs implies that neither a Salpeter nor a Scalo calibration factor applied to the global luminosity density will yield the true star formation rate. Secondly, even in the absence of this difference, the 200Â nm and HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ calibrations are not consistent because they refer to different averages over the recent star formation history. This can be seen clearly in FigureÂ 2, where the vB and Scd-Sdm components have identical values of RkHâ¢Î±â¢(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜Hğ›¼ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start H italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{k}^{{\rm H}\alpha}(t) after the initial transient phase of â‰ˆ10absent10RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:10\approx 10 Myr, but have different values of Rk200â¢(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜200ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:200 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{k}^{200}(t) except at 100 Myr.

Another way to view the discrepancy is to contrast the relative contribution of each galaxy type to the luminosity density with its contribution to the star formation rate. TableÂ 2 shows, for example, that at z=0ğ‘§0italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0z=0 the vB galaxy type contributes 32% to â„’Hâ¢Î±superscriptâ„’Hğ›¼caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start H italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal L}^{{\rm H}\alpha} and 27% to â„’200superscriptâ„’200caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:200 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal L}^{200}, while its contribution to the star formation rate itself is 24%.

At high redshift yet another factor comes into play: the relative mix of galaxy types changes as each undergoes luminosity evolution with its specified star formation history. The systematic errors seen at z=0ğ‘§0italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0z=0 therefore change with redshift. Not surprisingly, we see that for each waveband the Scalo IMF calibration is poorer than the Salpeter at z=0ğ‘§0italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0z=0, and that the situation reverses at z=2ğ‘§2italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2z=2, since the early-type galaxies become dominant at higher redshifts. There are, however, always systematic errors in the inferred star formation rates.

The qualitative trends in our results could have been anticipated on the basis of previous studies of the influence of the IMF and the star formation history on the calibration of luminosity densities in terms of star formation rates (e.g. Schaerer, 1999). Our study shows quantitatively that attempts to infer the SFR density locally and over a range of redshifts can be compromised by the presence of different galaxy types, whose mix evolves differentially. Such differential evolution is an almost inevitable consequence of models based on pure luminosity evolution or, indeed, other descriptions of cosmic evolution. Insofar as the model of Pozzetti et al. (1996) is typical in respect of its mixture of galaxy types, systematic errors can be anticipated of the order of a factor of at least 2 in both the absolute value of SFR and in its relative evolution in 0<z<20ğ‘§2NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-z RELOP:less-than NUMBER:20<z<2. Some of the intrinsic problems that arise from the adoption of fixed calibration factors for the relation between SFR density and luminosity density can be partially addressed by computing the luminosity density explicitly from a model universe for comparison with observations (cf. FigureÂ 1).

At first sight, the inconsistency between the SFR inferred from 200Â nm and HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ calibrations could be regarded as a serious problem. However, the difference between the two values contains potentially useful diagnostic power regarding the star formation history. Observations of a variety of different diagnostics of the star formation rate in a sample of galaxies could provide a more robustly constrained star formation history, by allowing the determination of other important factors (such as type-specific IMFs). However, the number of star formation diagnostics accessible to observation is not large, and there are many parameters to be constrained. Clearly, the possible existence of type-specific IMFs and star-formation histories presents a significant challenge to any systematic investigation of the cosmic evolution of star formation.

section.div: We wish to thank Michael Rowan-Robinson for helpful comments and suggestions. JA gratefully acknowledges support in the form of a scholarship from the Science and Technology Foundation (FCT, Portugal) through Program Praxis XXI.

The measurements adopt H0=65subscriptğ»065italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:65H_{0}=65Â kmÂ s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â Mpc-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Conversion to the cosmology used in this paper would reduce the measured luminosity density by â‰ˆ0.4absent0.4RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.4\approx 0.4 dex but a correction for UV extinction would increase the value by a similar amount.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: (a) The evolution with time of the ratio of SFR density to luminosity density at 200Â nm for each galaxy type considered in this study. The solid line represents the evolution of the global ratio of the total star formation rate density to luminosity density, R200â¢(t)superscriptğ‘…200ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:200 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R^{200}(t). (b) The same as (a), for HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha.

img.figcaption: Figure 3: Evolution of the SFR density for the 4 galaxy types, derived using the parametric SFRs and luminosity functions of Pozzetti et al.Â The solid curve represents the global SFR density.

Figure 4: Evolution of the estimated global SFR density, using the calibrations derived as explained in the text (Cpsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘italic-C POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC^{p}) and listed in TableÂ 1. There are calibrations for both Salpeter (late) and Scalo (early) IMFs. The solid curve is the actual global SFR density transferred from Fig. 3.
